review.title: Comparative Analysis of Probabilistic Models for Activity Recognition with an Instrumented Walker
review.abstract: Rollating walkers are popular mobility aids used by older adults to improve balance control. There is a need to automatically recognize the activities performed by walker users to better understand activity patterns, mobility issues and the context in which falls are more likely to happen. We design and compare several techniques to recognize walker related activities. A comprehensive evaluation with control subjects and walker users from a retirement community is presented.

metadata.title: Comparative Analysis of Probabilistic Models for Activity Recognition with an Instrumented Walker

sections.text: Rollators are popular mobility aids used by older adults to improve balance control. To better understand activity patterns, mobility problems and the context in which falls are more likely, the activities performed by walker users need to be automatically detected. We design and compare different techniques to detect walker-related activities.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Improving the quality of life of the ageing population is one of the central concerns of health care. Our long-term goal is to improve the usefulness of these devices by enabling them to perceive their environment and actively assist their users. We work with a multidisciplinary group that studies the use of roller walkers. We have access to a roller equipped with various sensors and cameras to monitor the user. We develop automated techniques to detect the activities of their users (e.g. walking, standing, turning, etc.) This problem is significant for kinesiologists who study the use of roller blades.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: In [1] Alwan et al. describe a method for assessing basic gait characteristics supported by the roller, including heel strokes, toe-off events, as well as step time, double support, and individual support phases to the right and left. These statistics are based on measuring the weight transfer between the user and the roller through two load cells in the handles of the roller. This work focuses on low gait statistics, where we are interested in recognizing complex behaviors at a high level. Hirata et al. [3] instructed a roller with sensors and actuators. They detect three user states: walking, stopping, and emergency (including falls). These states are derived based on the distance between the user and the roller (measured by a laser rangefinder) and the speed of the roller.

sections.heading: 3 Experimental Setup
sections.text: We have access to a roller developed by Tung et al. [9]. An image of the roller can be seen in Fig. 2. The roller is equipped with various sensors, including a 3-D accelerometer in the seat, a load cell in each leg, and a wheel encoder that measures wheel displacement. Sensor values vary from 0 to 216 − 1. Data is transmitted via Bluetooth to a PDA for detection at 50 Hz. In addition to these sensors, two cameras are located on the roller, one facing backwards and providing the video feed of the user's legs, the other facing forward and providing the video feed of the environment. The video frame rate is approximately 30 frames / second. To collect data for our models, we have designed and implemented two exhibits, which are described below:

sections.heading: 3.2 Experiment 2
sections.text: In a second experiment, we asked 8 regular Rollator users (ages 84 to 97) to follow the course shown in Figure 3. This experiment was conducted in the Village of Winston Park (retirement community in Kitchener, Ontario) and the participants were residents of this facility. In addition, we asked 12 adults (ages 80 to 89) who do not live in a retirement community and are not regular Rollator users to follow the same course. Behaviors shown during this experiment include those shown in Tables 1 and 2.

sections.heading: 3.3 Recognizing Behaviours
sections.text: We expect people's behavior to be based on the non-video sensors.1 Since the accelerometers, load cells and wheel encoders only indirectly measure the person's activities, it is not obvious which activities can be easily detected. We formulated the following hypotheses. However, the use of video data is the subject of future work. The person should be easy to predict as there is no load on the roller and the roller does not move. Standing (ST) should be distinguished from load cell measurements as load fluctuations when the person touches the roller. Walking forward (WF) and walking backward (WB) should be differentiated.

sections.heading: 4 Activity Recognition Models
sections.text: We assume that the set of all possible behaviors is B, the cardinality of which is m. The behavior at the time t is represented by the random variable Bt. The measurement at the sensor k at the time t is given by the random variable Skt, where k-value {1,..., n}. For the convenience of writing we denote the sequence of behaviors from the time i to j by Bi: j and the observation sequence at the sensor k by Ski: j. The measurements at all sensors observed between the time i and j are denoted by S1: ni: j and the actual observed sequence is denoted by s1: ni: j. The total length of a sequence is T. The actual behavior at the time t is denoted by b-value and the predicted behavior at the time t by b-value. Lower case letters denote the assignment of a value to a random variable.

sections.heading: 4.1 Hidden Markov Model
sections.text: We construct a hidden Markov model in which the behavior is the hidden variable and the sensor values are the observations (Fig. 4). Parameters include θb ′, b ≡ Pr (Bt = b ′ | Bt − 1 = b) (probability that the behavior is at the time t b ′ because the behavior is at the time t − 1 b), φs, k, b ≡ Pr (Skt = s | Bt = b) (probability that the value measured by the kth sensor at the time t is s that the behavior is b) and πb ≡ Pr (B0 = b) (probability that the initial behavior is b).

However, in some of our experiments we use a simple transition model to avoid bias, which reflects the fact that behavior is times more likely to change than not.

sections.heading: 4.1.2 Bayesian Learning
sections.text: We start from a previous distribution and update it with the help of the Bayes rule, in order to obtain the complete posterior distribution over the variables of interest. By looking at the complete posterior distribution over the parameters, we hope to avoid the overfitting problems that are often experienced by the EM algorithm. In most cases, the posterior distribution over the parameters does not have a tractable form, so we cannot fall back directly on it. Consequently, we resort to methods based on the simulation of a Markov chain, whose stationary distribution is the posterior distribution of interests. A convenient choice of a previous distribution over the parameters is a product of the Dir 1 Dirichlet distribution.

sections.heading: 4.2 Conditional Random Field
sections.text: We consider the particular case of the linear chain CRFs. A CRF defines the distribution of a sequence of thresholds (B1: t) conditioned on a sequence of observations (S1: n1: t). In our experiments, the labels are considered the behavior of the user, and the observations are the sensor measurements at any time. The probability of B1: t = b1: t conditioned on S1: n1: n1: t: t = s1: t is given.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: This work presented a novel and significant application of activity detection in the context of instrumented rollers. We developed several algorithms based on HMMs and CRFs and tested them with real users in the Village of Winston Park (retirement community in Kitchener, Ontario). A comprehensive analysis of the results showed that behaviors associated with the use of rollers tend to result in loads, speed, and acceleration patterns that are sufficient to distinguish them with reasonable accuracy. In the future, we would like to further improve detection accuracy by using the video data and studying various trait extraction techniques. We are also working to improve the battery life and storage capacity of the rollers to capture data over long periods of time. In particular, this will allow us to lend the rollers to users, record their daily use, and learn realistic and personalized behavioral transition models. Finally, we hope to translate this work into a clinical tool to evaluate the likelihood of using them in the context of mobility patterns.
